action.action-desc: Mr. Reed (for himself and Mr. Thompson of California) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to improve access to hospice care under the Medicare program, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may cited as the Hospice Care Access Improvement Act of 2015.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Health and Human Services (in this Act referred to as the Secretary) shall conduct a demonstration program for a 1-year period during fiscal year 2016 to test the proposed hospice payment methodology revisions.

subsection.header: Proposed Hospice Payment Methodology Revisions defined
subsection.text: In this section, the term proposed hospice payment methodology revisions means revisions to the methodology for determining hospice payment rates under section 1814(i)(6)(D) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395f(i)(6)(D)) contained in the Fiscal Year 2016 Hospice Wage Index and Payment Rate Update and Hospice Quality Reporting Requirements as published by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services on May 5, 2015 (80 Fed. Reg. 25831 et seq.).

The Secretary shall select one Medicare administrative contractor to conduct the demonstration program. Such contractor shall conduct the demonstration program with respect to all hospice programs under that contractor’s jurisdiction.
The Secretary shall conduct an evaluation of the demonstration program, which shall include an analysis of the impact of the proposed hospice payment methodology revisions—

paragraph.text: on the quality of patient care and the ability of hospice programs to provide such care; and
on access to hospice care for beneficiaries.

subsection.text: Not later than March 31, 2017, the Secretary shall submit to Congress a report on the demonstration program. The report shall include—

paragraph.text: the results of the evaluation under subsection (d); and
recommendations for such legislation and administrative action as the Secretary determines appropriate.

subsection.header: Implementation of hospice payment methodology revisions

paragraph.header: Prohibition on implementation of revisions for fiscal years 2016 and 2017
paragraph.text: No revisions to the hospice payment methodology shall be made under section 1814(i)(6)(D) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395f(i)(6)(D)) for fiscal years 2016 and 2017, except for purposes of the demonstration program required to be conducted under subsection (a).

paragraph.header: Implementation of revisions for fiscal year 2018
paragraph.text: After taking into account the results of the evaluation of the demonstration program and after making any necessary revisions, the Secretary shall implement the proposed hospice payment methodology revisions beginning with fiscal year 2018.

subsection.header: Medical review for certain hospice programs
subsection.text: Section 1814(i) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395f(i)) is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Medical review for certain hospice programs

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall implement a process for the medical review of hospice care furnished by a hospice program identified under subparagraph (B).

subparagraph.header: Identification of hospice programs for medical review
subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall identify hospice programs the patients of which will be subject to medical review under subparagraph (A). In identifying such programs, the Secretary shall consider multiple factors in comparison with other similarly situated hospice programs, such as—

clause.text: the percentage of patients who were discharged after receiving hospice care for a period of 120 to 180 days and who were alive upon such discharge;
the percentage of patients who are receiving hospice care from the program at the end of life who receive no skilled hospice care visits in the last week of life; and
the level of per-patient expenditures under this title for patients of the hospice program excluding expenditures for hospice care.

subparagraph.header: Limitation on liability of beneficiary where medicare claims are disallowed
subparagraph.text: The provisions of this title relating to the limitation on liability of a beneficiary where Medicare claims are disallowed shall apply with respect to this paragraph in the same manner as they apply to subsection (a)(7)(E).

subsection.header: Developing interventions To reduce hospital admissions
subsection.text: The Secretary shall develop and publish guidance, where appropriate and in consultation with interested parties, for hospice programs to develop interventions to reduce hospital admissions and visits to hospital emergency departments by patients of such hospice programs.

subsection.header: Expanding who may perform pre-Hospice evaluation and counseling services

paragraph.text: Section 1812(a)(5) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395d(a)(5)) is amended by inserting after hospice program the following: , or services that are furnished by a registered nurse who is an employee of a hospice program in consultation, if necessary, with other members of the interdisciplinary group described in section 1861(dd)(2)(B),.

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall evaluate the impact of the amendment made by paragraph (1). Such evaluation shall include an evaluation of the impact of such amendment on hospital admission rates, hospice care utilization, and length of stay in hospice programs for patients receiving services under section 1812(a)(5) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395d(a)(5)).
The Secretary shall submit a report to Congress containing the results of the evaluation under subparagraph (A).

subsection.header: Expanding hospice care access for residents using skilled nursing facilities

paragraph.text: Section 1819 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395i–3) is amended—

subparagraph.text: in subsection (b)(4), by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:

In the case of a facility that contracts with a hospice program for hospice care for its residents, such facility shall make a good faith effort to enter into a contract with more than one hospice program participating under this title that provides services in the area served by the facility, if more than one hospice program is available to serve such residents.

in subsection (c)(1)(A)(i), by inserting after well-being, the following: to be fully informed, in a form and manner specified by the Secretary, of any financial interest, as specified by the Secretary, the skilled nursing facility has in any hospice program to which a resident is referred,.

paragraph.text: The amendments made by this subsection shall apply to skilled nursing facilities in operation 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act.

subsection.header: Hospital discharge planning provisions relating to hospice care

paragraph.text: Section 1861(ee)(2) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395x(ee)(2)) is amended—

subparagraph.text: in subparagraph (D), by striking the period at the end and inserting and, in the case of individuals likely to need hospice care, the availability of such care through hospice programs that participate in the program under this title and that serve the area in which the patient resides and that request to be listed by the hospital as available.; and
in subparagraph (H)(i), by inserting or hospice care after home health services.

paragraph.text: The amendments made by this subsection shall apply to discharges occurring on or after 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.
